Post.title: Zapatitos Converse
Post._content:
Me declaro un fanco de los tenis Converse, slo por ello tengo cuatro pares de dicha marca. A veces creo que tengo demasiados tenis y zapatos, haciendo un conteo mental rpido puedo recordar, de tenis (o zapatillas, como les dicen en Sudamrica) esos cuatro pares y dos pares ms de distintas marcas cada uno. Adems, tengo como cinco pares de zapatos y un par de chanclas. Quizs son demasiados?

Bueno, pero pasando a lo que realmente me compete en este post, hablar sobre mis pares de tenis Converse.



Los primeros zapatitos, los negros, son los ms viejos que tengo, me gustan mucho ms los modelos nuevos de Converse (como los otros tres). Si ven la foto fjamente se darn cuenta de que estn rayados a cuadritos en las orillas. Ese es un sntoma de mi vieja etapa de skatito loco inhala-monas ;) Antes de esos tenis tuve otros que adoraba, unos idnticos pero de un color como azul metlico con hilos y costuras en anaranjado, bastante fresas, pero muy bonitos. Terminaron en la basura cuando ya estaban muy rotos (lo cual decidi tirnicamente mi madre :-O).

Los rojos son quizs los que ms quiero. Son los que me han acompaado durante ms tiempo, fueron a Brasil, fueron a Espaa, han estado en todos lados conmigo. Son precisamente los que me puse hoy (por eso se ve que los traigo puestos).

Los terceros son los ms nuevos, los compr en Liverpool un da que los vi. Tena muchas ganas de tenis de bota y esos fueron justamente los ideales. An no han sido lavados ni una sola vez, lo cual es algo resaltable :D. Y pues quizs algn da puedan ser tan amados como son ahora los rojitos. Quizs lo nico que les cambiara sera el color blanco del borde superior: Me gustara tambin que fueran azules :-P

Los ltimos, los azules con verde fosforecentelctrico son los que menos uso, quizs precisamente por ese tipo de color. Adems, la tela es demasiado suave para mi gusto (no son iguales a los otros) y no me siento tan cmodo. Por ello tambin es que no tienen agujetas: Los lavaron y no he tenido ni tiempo, ni ganas para ponerle las agujetas ;)

Pues bueno, es todo por ahora. Creo que hay que tener o mucho tiempo libre, o muy pocas ganas de hacer lo que debera de hacer como para ponerme a hablar de mis tenis. Qu cosas, no?

Post.title: YouTube's HTML5 trial opt-in
Post._content: If you use any non-retarded Web browser (aka not Internet Explorer) and usually run into and enjoy the huge inventory of videos that YouTube has to offer, please consider opting in to YouTube's HTML5 trial, which means that you'll be running HTML5 browser-based video instead of Flash for most of the website's videos. If you're also nerd enough, make sure to send them feedback and shit.

Post.title: Yo pecador
Post._content:
He pecado.

Durante varias semanas y meses, me hice a la idea de que mi computadora no se llevaba bien con Linux. Y me forc a usar MacOS. Ms por obligacin que por gusto. Me retir un rato de Debian, argumentando que le pondra ms atencin a otras cosas como la escuela o el trabajo. Lleg un momento en el que me volv el novio favorito de la piratera: Me coquetaba a cada rato, lo que quera lo bajaba con un torrent con el cliente propietario de BitTorrent. Usaba Apple Mail. Dej las listas de Debian. Lo nico que mantena relacionado, era Planeta Linux, con mi subversion importado desde Fink en la ms terrible y abominable de los emuladores de terminal que el hombre haya jams concebido: Terminal.

Usaba Microsoft Office para ver las presentaciones tontas que mandan en cadena en la oficina. Us Word para escribir un texto que nunca termin y nunca mand para Alternativa. Baj Mathematica pirata y nunca lo pude jalar porque peda mucha autenticacin que no pude conseguir por Internet (llaves, confirmaciones, etc). Prefer software propietario a libre. Dije que Linux an no estaba preparado para correr en un escritorio: Me disfrac, me mimetic. Usaba Preview para ver mis PDFs y iTunes para escuchar mi msica. Escuchaba podcasts con iTunes. Me adecu al software que tena a mi alrededor y no el software se adecu a m, como generalmente pasa con software libre.

Y de repente volte para atrs y vi todo lo que dejaba, lo que haba hecho y lo que poda seguir haciendo. Empec a hacer algunas cosas con Jordi que necesitaba acceso remoto a servidores. Terminal no me ayud, ni iTerm, ni muchos otros muy pendejos proyectos similares. Me hart de los acentos en las terminales. Tato me joda con que dejara la mierda de MacOS: Me conoce bien, aunque luego noms le gusta hacerle a la mamada.
Y mand todo a la chingada.

Y heme aqu otra vez. Pensando muchos proyectos ms, con el Debian que siempre deb tener instalado. Pelendome con el bluetooth y con la suspensin. Con el teclado en X. Dejndolo a mi gusto. Si no me gusta algo a mi alrededor, seguramente lo puedo modificar, lo puedo poner a mi gusto. Vuelvo a la flexibilidad de Mutt, aunque ella me pregunte, “por qu ves as el correo?”. Porque me gusta. Porque me apasiona. Porque encuentro en el software libre un mundo que ha transformado mi vida desde hace apenas casi cinco aos. Porque me ha trado de los mejores amigos, de las mejores personas y de los mejores lugares que he conocido jams en mi vida.

Estoy de vuelta y recargado. Y de no haber sido por el puto y miserable manejo que tuve con mi dominio en das pasados, ya habra empezado a disparar a diestra y siniestra.

Ahora s: Ah les voy, cabrones.

Post.title: Yes
Post._content:
I just told my boss. I’m moving to Venezuela. It’s now official. Everybody knew, except for my boss and he supports me completely: He rocks. Well, it somewhat depends on the definition of ‘moving’, but I’ll be there for more than a couple of months, call it whatever you want.

I’m pretty excited. Time to get tickets. And time to plan actually, again, going to DebConf, which is, from an specific point of view, quite funny .

For all of them who have asked me for some spare space at my place in Mexico City, it’ll be available from May 4th to 24th. But feel free to mail me or drop a line on IRC if you need some space somewhere before or after that period, I have plenty of friends (both geeky and not ) who would like to host people for a few days.

Now, should I start a petition online in order to abrotman gets decided and come to DebConf?

Post.title: Yellow bar
Post._content:
The roundtable/BOF in DebConf5 about Debian website was quite interesting, although I didn’t participate much, but I was widely interested on listening to every opinion out there about it, since the website is one of my big concerns on the project.

There, I proposed a navigation bar to be included on the header of each page, displaying the path you have followed, between the directories of the website (the webwml tree). I think the physical placement of the files and directories can be an advantage and would be significantly easy to work with on something like this. Peter Karlson didn’t agree, since he thinks lots of work has to be done to have a decent placement for all the files (in fact, he said one thing quite interesting which I also have realized in the past: You can always discover cool pages you have never seen before, in the Debian website, while working on wml translations).

Anyway, I still think the navigation bar (not the one called navbar, already used) can be a good and interesting thing to start playing with, it probably could give the www team the reason to begin reorganization of the files on the tree. And well, the biggest concern on the people attending the talks around Debian website was usability, and this is my very first small step towards real answers. I still have to bring this to the discussion on the mailing list, though.

So, last night I started hacking a bit my local webwml tree (with a 12-beer night break) and ended (not yet really: more CSS design has to be done and probably the way I’m doing it can be improved) with something like this:



A rounded left border would be nice, I think. The bar does not interfer with anything in any page and the Perl code is minimal.

If somebody out there has any kind of comment, please let me know, probably I’m just doing it the wrong way, because of (I don’t know) any reason.

Post.title: Yeah Yeah Yeahs and Corona Music Fest
Post._content: I had an exhausting and stressing weekend. We had a long long holiday this week in Mexico. Some people had the week until Tuesday and had from Wednesday to Sunday off, because of the Day of the Dead celebration (being Nov 1st and 2nd, and taking Friday 3rd also). I didn’t have any classes, but the Superior Algebra teacher made us attend an exam on Friday and Saturday (9 am and 8 am, respectively). Some of my friends were high and drunk from Tuesday afternoon and will remain that way until tomorrow, while I had to stay at home and work stressing for my poor understanding on the class, trying to study with tons of things on my head, etc. This so much sucks. Anyway, last week, Raquel, Tato, Javier and a friend of Tato managed to go to Yeah Yeah Yeahs’ concert, which was fucking amazing. I love Karen O, her sex appeal and the way she does to put people in the mood is great and lovely. Unfortunately, Rach hasn’t put the pics (we got her digital camera inside the building but was discovered by the staff and forced to put it on a stuff hold table, fuckers) yet, I hope she does soon :) The best moment of the concert: Date with the Night. Next weekend, the Corona Music Fest will take place in the Azteca stadium, which has me anxious. I can’t wait to watch The Mars Volta on stage. Other nice bands I’m expecting to watch are NOFX, Clap Your Hands Say Yeah, Resorte, La Gusana Ciega and the Nortec Collective. Here’s the flyer:

Post.title: YAPC::NA 2008
Post._content:
So I attended the conference last week in Chicago, IL. I was just been procrastinating to write about this. As a (almost) complete outsider of the Perl community, I have countered thoughts about the whole event:
  • I was actually expecting a deeper technical content on some of the talks.
  • Some speakers were just very bad at presenting, they were either boring with a very exciting topic or lacked the spark to get the audience attentive.
  • Some people on the IRC channel kept criticizing what some (not very known in the Perl circle) speakers were talking about. For instance, the usual stupid argument of "why to do this, if we can already make it with...", or "yeah, but we can do that with Foo::Bar and ZMOFGML". After all, just as Andy Lester once wrote, let's see people's work, let's see their new ideas or new ways to implement things. Heck, TIMTOFWTDI.
  • Wireless connectivity was very poor, apparently due to ad-hoc nodes and malware on the cloud.
  • Since I'm used to DebConfs, it was nice to see, though, a job fair and some circles discussing new ways to do business with Perl development.
  • Around 40% of the attendees were attending their actual first YAPC. Apparently, there are a lot of newcomers to Perl conferences, but they usually don't come back that often or get a bit scared.
  • Being a community conference, makes it, after all, a bit special. YAPC was mostly, as Jos Castro stated, just about people and beer.
  • Organizers gave their best to make this happen successfully, you could see, feel that.
  • I met some guys that after introducing us, I was confused were they were from, which was mainly because of my huge ignorance of US geography. For instance, people would tell they are from South Benton, from Omaha or from Columbus, between others. At the moment I felt it'd be tacky to ask on what states those cities are on, but now I know ;) Indiana, Nebraska and Ohio. Heh.
  • Chicago is a beautiful city and stuffed pizza kicks ass.
  • What I liked from the Perl community: They usually get things done and don't fool around too much with senseless shit.
  • What I didn't like: If you are not a regular into the circle, it's quite difficult to feel involved or part of it. To this, add being from another country :P
  • What I liked the most on talks: Ricardo SIGNES's talk about email which was awesome and the lightning talks (specially the improvised ones).
After all, it was quite a nice and new experience. I'm not totally sure I'll attend YAPC::NA 2009 in Pittsburgh, PA, we'll see.

Post.title: YAPC::EU::2009 fail
Post._content: Given an awful work/travel schedule that I couldn't handle in the last days, I wasn't able to get to Lisbon, Portugal to attend YAPC::EU, until today, day one of the conference, I was still looking forward to get a cheapish flight from Madrid, but it was just impossible, schedules wouldn't match with my work and vacation plans. Bummer. Because of this, I will not be able to give my talk Perl in the Time of Social Networks (that I had already revisited and improved) there as it was expected for tomorrow. No YAPC Europe for me :( At least not this year, *sob, sob*

Post.title: Yahoo! YSlow for Firebug
Post._content:
During last weekend's WordCamp, Jeremy Clarke gave a bunch of tips for websites server optimizations (I'll summarize my views on his talk later on a separate post) and he showcased a plugin for Firebug that I didn't know about and caught my attention: Yahoo! YSlow. It is a really nice piece of software, it adds a tab on your Firebug window and will grade the performance of the web page you are browsing with a set of tips on how to make it faster, ranging from images, CSS, JavaScript, headers, etc:

I find this to not be the ultimate solution to fix your websites' loading speed of course, but something advisable to use and try to comply against.

I believe it's time for me to get my blog from D to A :)
Post.raw:
title: "Yahoo! YSlow for Firebug" date: 2009/11/16 18:45:23 tags: - firebug - firefox - optimization - web - yahoo - yslow --- During last weekend's WordCamp, Jeremy Clarke gave a bunch of tips for websites server optimizations (I'll summarize my views on his talk later on a separate post) and he showcased a plugin for Firebug that I didn't know about and caught my attention: Yahoo! YSlow. It is a really nice piece of software, it adds a tab on your Firebug window and will grade the performance of the web page you are browsing with a set of tips on how to make it faster, ranging from images, CSS, JavaScript, headers, etc:

I find this to not be the ultimate solution to fix your websites' loading speed of course, but something advisable to use and try to comply against.

I believe it's time for me to get my blog from D to A :)

Post.title: X-Chat madness and FFII
Post._content:
So, lately I’ve been over IRC spending lots of time.I started using xchat-gnome but it really seems to young, it doesn’t implement much features and crashes lots of times.

So, I continued using normal X-Chat, and the madness is all the channels I’m logged in anytime.

So, Martin Michlmayr, the current Debian Project Leader, sent an email for debian-project mailing list inviting to donate to FFII: 

FFII supports the development of public
information goods based on copyright, free competition, and open
standards.  Some of their current activities are directed against
software patents in Europe, and given that software patents are
potentially a big risk for free software and Debian, I think this
effort should be supported us.  I see this donation only as a first
step and feel that Debian should actively speak out against software
patents.  I encourage members and users of Debian to get involved
with or donate to FFII and tell others about the dangers of software
patents.

Smooth. That is hugely interesting. If you are able, please support.

Current Mood: grumpy Current Music: System of a Down - Sugar

Post.title: WWW::Tumblr
Post._content: After a while, I ended up building WWW::Tumblr (implementing the Tumblr API), so that Blog::Normalize::Tumblr can easily replace scrapping. The interesting part would be to write small applications to interact with the WWW::Tumblr to handle your tumblelog. Only file uploads missing for now. For now.

Post.title: WWW::Tumblr 5.00
Post._content: A few years ago, back when Tumblr had not been valued a billion dollars, I wrote WWW::Tumblr, which was basically Perl bindings for their REST API. Then I forgot about it for a long time, then Yahoo! bought them or something like that. I ended up getting contacted by some Perl programmers, telling me that they were using the Perl module. Great! Anyway, following the general rule on Internet startups, Tumblr migrated most of their endpoints to OAuth and left a bunch of other resources changed to use an API key and others not. Joy. I gotta say that at this point I was't interested on Tumblr too much, in spite of having a profile that followed a few very random blogs. But people were indeed interested on the module for their own stuff and I got contacted again a few times. Anyway, my coworker Fernando brought it to my attention more and more and I re-started working on my OAuth branch. A few weeks later now, I present you WWW::Tumblr 5.00, which supports all of the methods from the new Tumblr v2 API. During the development phase, Fernando tested a whole bunch, as well as this other project: I am very thankful for their help, since it took a while to properly make the API work as Tumblr does not seem to have the most compliant OAuth implementation of them all, and they seem to be quite unimpressed with questions and inquiries on their development group, but what are you gonna do about it, right, *sigh*. Anyway, head to MetaCPAN to grab your copy today! And report bugs and stuff to the GitHub repo.

Post.title: Writing Secure WordPress Plugins talk by Mark Jaquith
Post._content:
Continuing my notes and remarks from WordCamp, I attended Writing Secure Plugins, which was given by Mark Jaquith (@markjaquith on Twitter). I found the talk to be also slightly introductory on security matters but nicely oriented to WordPress plugins and general PHP Web app development. I believe most of the tips given should be taken into consideration by every PHP coder out there, not just WP people.

The talk was split into the different attacks that are common on Web applications and mainly pointing to functions and actions to be taken. Here are my notes:

SQL injection

  • esc_sql(), allows you to escape SQL queries.
  • absint(), allows to convert an ID value to its positive integer value to prevent ID injection.
  • $wpdb->update(), a WordPress API method to update data.
  • $wpdb->insert(), a WordPress API method to insert new data rows.
  • compact(), PHP core function that lets you use variable names as strings.
  • $wpdb->prepare(), crafts a secure SQL statement with placeholders.
  • $wpdb->get_var(), returns a single variable from WordPress data.

Cross-site scripting (XSS)

  • "Everything is suspicious".
  • esc_attr_e(), escapes a translated string to be used as an HTML tag attribute.
  • esc_html(), escapes general HTML.
  • esc_attr(), escapes a string for tag attribute.
  • esc_url(), encodes URL.
  • esc_url_raw(), encodes URL without HTML entities to be encoded.
  • esc_js(), encodes JavaScript code.

Cross-site request forgery (CSRF)

  • Understand the difference between authorization and intention.
  • Nonces (token handling).
  • wp_nonce_field() and then, check_admin_referer().
  • current_user_can(), API capability checking.

AJAX CSRF

  • &_ajax_nonce = NONCE

Privilege escalation

Stupid shit!

  • Avoid exec() at all costs!
  • Use blank or hardcoded paths instead of $_SERVER['REQUEST_URI'] on form submission.

Presentation
Post.raw:

I found the talk to be also slightly introductory on security matters but nicely oriented to WordPress plugins and general PHP Web app development.   • $wpdb->update(), a WordPress API method to update data.
  • $wpdb->insert(), a WordPress API method to insert new data rows.
  • compact(), PHP core function that lets you use variable names as strings.
  • $wpdb->prepare(), crafts a secure SQL statement with placeholders.
  • $wpdb->get_var(), returns a single variable from WordPress data.

Cross-site scripting (XSS)

  • "Everything is suspicious".
  • esc_attr_e(), escapes a translated string to be used as an HTML tag attribute.
  • esc_html(), escapes general HTML.
  • esc_attr(), escapes a string for tag attribute.
  • esc_url(), encodes URL.
  • esc_url_raw(), encodes URL without HTML entities to be encoded.
  • esc_js(), encodes JavaScript code.

  • Understand the difference between authorization and intention.
  • Nonces (token handling).
  • wp_nonce_field() and then, check_admin_referer().
  • current_user_can(), API capability checking.

Post.title: World Cup just around the corner
Post._content:
Well, Mexico played three preparation games in Europe on their way to start the World Cup. They played against France and the Netherlands on their territories and well, I think Mexico was not ready enough, it is not solid and the manager was making lots of crazy movements. They ended 1-0 and 2-1, respectively. Obviously those were difficult matches against ftbol potences on their home, but still Mexico has plenty of capacity to beat any of those countries.

The third game was against a German university, Gottingen, which was more a diplomatic match (the manager and players didn’t want to play it, but it was because of the chief managers of Mexico, trying to make a good relationship with the city and/or Germany, itself). We won 0-3.

Next week, on Friday, the World Cup will begin. The Mexican team will be playing firstly, against Iran, then Angola and finally Portugal, on group D. I don’t see Mexico solid and trustable enough yet, but we’ll see how it goes against Iran, which have been playing widely good (they won Costa Rica 3-2, back in March; drew 2-2 with Croatia and won 5-2 against Bosnia-Herzegovina; these last two in the last couple of days). Iran is not at all, an easy enemy.

We’ll see how it goes. I’ll be reporting more World Cup news on the next weeks :)

Post.title: Attending WordCamp NYC
Post._content: I'll be attending WordCamp NYC this upcoming weekend. There's a lot of very interesting talks and people speaking at the conference, so it was basically a no-brainer since it's being held in Manhattan. Post.title: Wonderful WordCamp NYC experience
Post._content: I had a blast on Saturday. Let me put it again in bold, I had an awesome experience yesterday at WordCamp NYC. If you ever have the opportunity, you shouldn't miss the chance to attend one of them, it's really inspiring, people is very, very welcome and I loved the fact that there's so many people with all sorts of backgrounds and focused on many fronts on the Web and blogging world, not just technical. During the course of this starting week, I'll be posting my notes and remarks on each one of the talks I attended, I believe they do require their own attention. With as much as eight simultaneous tracks, it was pretty much impossible to hear them all, so I focused on technical talks (go figure) and on the "beginning developer" track, since I pretty much knew close to nothing when it comes to WordPress core development. Unfortunately I couldn't attend Sunday sessions due to health issues. I'm seriously sorry about that. Anyhow, to be honest, I cannot easily recall another conference that left me with such a nice feeling after attending it. Also, expect more blogging here. :)

Post.title: WNPP massive close
Post._content:
Today I have closed 729 work-needing and prospective packages bugs :-)

156 of them were ITPs and the rest 573, RFPs. All of them were bugs with a lifetime greater than 600 days old. Most of the ITPs closed were inactive bugs for more than almost two years. The RFPs were not consulted on this. Blame me if something went wrong with it.

And please, do not complain about this: If people is still interested on their packages, they are free, as usual, to reopen them. Let this also work as a ping to inactive wnpp bugs.

Please, think on the effort that several people (not only one or two persons) are doing to clean the wnpp place a bit. Specially think on the effort and hours spent there when sending ironic subjects on your mails to control@b.d.o reopening your bugs.

More work on this front will be done in the next days.

Post.title: Why am I writing in English?
Post._content:
I have received several comments on why am I writing my blog in English, since many of the Mexican guys involved on free software who own a blog and use to blog periodicly, dont. Obviously I had to talk about this some time because it is not usual.

  • i18n. Do you really do not understand English? Or probably my English? If you do, who cares?
  • Reach. It is widely know English reaches more people than only a few people. I have the crazy idea that some, at least one, non Spanish speaker, would read my blog.
  • I can. I write in English because I can. WYSIWYG.
  • Anonymous. While I get anonymous posts about writing in English, I will keep on doing it. If you really cant tell me things face to face, then I dont give a shit about cowards.
  • Why not? Why not write my blog entries in English?

Post.title: Who could tell it better than Him?
Post._content:
“Ruby is an object-oriented programming language developed for the purpose of making programming both enjoyable and fast. With its easy-to-use interpreter, easy-to-understand syntax, complete object-oriented functionality, and powerful class libraries, Ruby has become a language that can be used in a broad range of fields: from text processing and CGI scripts to professional, large-scale programs.

“As a programmer and a programming-language geek, I know what makes me happy while programming, and I designed Ruby with these elements in mind. I based the language on an object-oriented paradigm, provided a solid feature set (e.g., exceptions, iterators, etc.), and made sure to keep things consistent and balanced. Ruby will help you concentrate on solving problems. It is straightforward and not the least bit enigmatic.

“It’s my sincere hope that this book will help you enjoy programming in Ruby.

Happy programming!

-Yukihiro “Matz” Matsumoto, Japan.

Current Mood: sleepy
Current Music: All The People featuring Rober - Cramp Your Style

Post.title: Weird
Post._content:
It’s extremely weird when sometimes happen what some friends and I lived yesterday. Let me tell you:

We (some friends and I) had a couple of parties to go to. The first one was with my good friend Zilus, on a zone called Tecamachalco (which is a little far away from my home, but closer to university). He said pretty ladies were going to be there, as well as good music and environment. So, I decided to go. But before going to pick up my girl, I called Chema (another friend) to see if he had something else. He did.

- Chema: “Yeah, Promis has a party on Pedregal, one of his friends from work (he, Promis, works on a Starbucks Coffee Station).
- damog: I have a party on Tecamachalco.
- Chema: So, it’s up to you.
- damog: OK, yeah, I think I prefer to go with you guys, so I’ll go pick up Raquel and then I’m on your home.

So, I picked her up, and went to Chema’s apartment. Promis lives on the same building than Chema, so they were waiting for us (Raq and I) already. So I called them by ringing my car’s horn. In the meantime, I was talking with Raq:

- damog: I think I don’t want to go with my car today, what do you think if I leave my car at my house, and hop in the Promis’ car.
- Raq: Yeah, sounds good to me.

The only problem there was to schedule the return way. So, I asked by phone another friend (Joss) if he could bring us back (Raq and I live very close each other). He accepted. We left my car on my car and went to meet some other friends at Huevo’s house (Huevo is, of course, his nickname).

At Huevo’s it was Frijol and Jeric, some other friends. So we were waiting to some other guys and friends, as long as I can remember: Mueco, Marcial, Barney, Trompiate, Karla and other 5 guys, which I don’t know very well, I think.

After that, some other friends of friends invited more friends to come to the party. At a certain moment, we arrived, finally, to the house were the party was going to be held, around midnight. We were, surprisingly, around 20 people! I remember Orkut with that: Friends inviting friends to get involved. It was awesome how that can be conformed.

Anyway, all of us were following Promis, which was the contact there. But the things began to become worst: It was not a party, which all of us really thought (we were carrying some bottles of rum, tequila and beer). It was like a very close meeting! And the worst part: A very rude sir opened the door and saw us with a horrible and anger face asking what were we doing there. Promis said we came with Yaqui (apparently, his daughter) to the party.

The father closed the door and went to talk with the girl. After a couple of minutes, she opened the door and let us get in. The house was enormous, with a long yard and even a swimming pool (it is not very common to have a swimming pool in Mexico City) and a bunch of young, bastard and stupid snobs in the yard.

So, we tried to just ignore the fact that most of us were not on the right place, with not the right people and began to drink a little bit, joking around. I have to say that the father was on a balcony watching us every time.

After a couple of minutes, more people, around 10 or 15 (our friends of friends) arrived! So we were like 30 or 35 guys, with like a social network!

And finally the moment everyone was thinking it was going to occur, the father told the daughter to tell us to leave. So, we left the house, like if we were like a bunch of criminals. I bet we all are more easy going than the other rich bastards. Besides, we heard that the father was some kind of cop. Corrupt and stupid cop.

Anyway, we went to some other party, in a zone called Las guilas, which is a zone more familiar, not so snob. But they didn’t let us get in, because the party was dying already (it was around 1:30 am). So we decided to go Frijol’s apartment: Around 25 guys.

And we finally died there: Drinking, smoking and having good time with good friends.

The weird thing is the fact that we could get a party and they threw us like trash to the streets :-( Not once: Twice.

Hell.

Current Mood: weird
Current Music: Thee 50’s High Teens - Dance Little Sister

- damog: I think I don’t want to go with my car today, what do you think if I leave my car at my house, and hop in the Promis’ car.
- Raq: Yeah, sounds good to me.

The only problem there was to schedule the return way. So, I asked by phone another friend (Joss) if he could bring us back (Raq and I live very close each other). He accepted. We left my car on my car and went to meet some other friends at Huevo’s house (Huevo is, of course, his nickname).

At Huevo’s it was Frijol and Jeric, some other friends. So we were waiting to some other guys and friends, as long as I can remember: Mueco, Marcial, Barney, Trompiate, Karla and other 5 guys, which I don’t know very well, I think.

After that, some other friends of friends invited more friends to come to the party. At a certain moment, we arrived, finally, to the house were the party was going to be held, around midnight. We were, surprisingly, around 20 people! I remember Orkut with that: Friends inviting friends to get involved. It was awesome how that can be conformed.

Anyway, all of us were following Promis, which was the contact there. But the things began to become worst: It was not a party, which all of us really thought (we were carrying some bottles of rum, tequila and beer). It was like a very close meeting! And the worst part: A very rude sir opened the door and saw us with a horrible and anger face asking what were we doing there. Promis said we came with Yaqui (apparently, his daughter) to the party.

The father closed the door and went to talk with the girl. After a couple of minutes, she opened the door and let us get in. The house was enormous, with a long yard and even a swimming pool (it is not very common to have a swimming pool in Mexico City) and a bunch of young, bastard and stupid snobs in the yard.

So, we tried to just ignore the fact that most of us were not on the right place, with not the right people and began to drink a little bit, joking around. I have to say that the father was on a balcony watching us every time.

After a couple of minutes, more people, around 10 or 15 (our friends of friends) arrived! So we were like 30 or 35 guys, with like a social network!

And finally the moment everyone was thinking it was going to occur, the father told the daughter to tell us to leave. So, we left the house, like if we were like a bunch of criminals. I bet we all are more easy going than the other rich bastards. Besides, we heard that the father was some kind of cop. Corrupt and stupid cop.

Anyway, we went to some other party, in a zone called Las guilas, which is a zone more familiar, not so snob. But they didn’t let us get in, because the party was dying already (it was around 1:30 am). So we decided to go Frijol’s apartment: Around 25 guys.

And we finally died there: Drinking, smoking and having good time with good friends.

The weird thing is the fact that we could get a party and they threw us like trash to the streets :-( Not once: Twice.

Hell.

Current Mood: weird
Current Music: Thee 50’s High Teens - Dance Little Sister

Post.title: Week in Guadalajara
Post._content:
This incoming week will be madness. Two main things will happen. Im giving a talk at Festival de Software Libre in Gualadajara, on thrusday. It will be about colaboration in free software projects, focused on Debian. The other important thing to do is a physics exam on Friday, so it will be madness to cover both things, and try to not lose more classes than the ones I will, so this is my plan:

  • Monday 27 th. I have to finish a homework for Tuesday, and it is long. I only have one day left for deliver it, so the entire day I have to work on it.
  • Tuesday 28 th. Deliver my homework at 9 am, hopefully finished. Stay on that class until the end (around 11 am). Go the office (FYI I work in the university, so the office is pretty close from the classroom) and pick up my stuff (Ive already informed I was missing almost the entire week). Get on the bus with Tacvbo at 12:30 pm. Then wed spend 7/8 hours within the bus until we reach Guadalajara.
  • Wednesday 29 th. Watch Tacvbos talk about Gentoo and scream about its disadvantages . The entire day, I would spend it finishing my presentation.
  • Thrusday 30 th. Give my talk at 11 am. Eat lunch at midday. Take a bus around 4 pm in order to return to Mexico City. In the meantime, being in the bus, I have to study physics for my exam, that will be the only moment alone where Im going to be able to study. Arriving estimated time: Midnight.
  • Friday 1st Oct. Wake up at 6 am for my Calculus class at 7, and my Physics exam at 9. Then I would go to work. Then, go to eat and spend the noon with Rachel. Thats it. That is evil plan for this week. I hope I could post activities everyday. See ya!

Post.title: Vitacilina now in Debian + 0.2 released!
Post._content: Remember Vitacilina? A small aggregation library I wrote last year to be intended to replace Planet on Planeta Linux? Well, it never quite replaced it but it achieved some level of stability since I was using it for a number of tasks at work. So, during this long holiday weekend, I received a notification that the Request To Package bug I had filled against the Work-Needing and Prospective Packages in Debian has already been taken care of and the library had been uploaded. Of course, I could have made this myself a long time ago, but at the time it was simpler and faster just to hope someone else would do it at some point. So, Dario did it. He packaged it and uploaded version 0.1 under the umbrella of the Debian Perl Group. Hurray! But then I realized that Alexandr Ciornii had implemented some nice changes to Vitacilina back in September that I never got to include or release as a CPAN distribution. And so I just did. I've uploaded 0.2 to CPAN and you can fetch it with cpanf Vitacilina or wait for the Debian Perl folks to update it :)

Post.title: Visit counter
Post._content:
Pues bueno, luego de casi dos meses de prometer un visit counter (que se diferenca de un hit counter debido a que el hit counter suma cada recarga del sitio y el visit counter lo hace con cada IP), est listo. Para instalarlo, hay que instalar antes el hit_counter (para la creacin de las tablas en la base de datos, etc.). Las explicaciones para instalar el hit_counter estn ac. Una vez instalado el hit_counter, hay que reemplazar el hit_counter.php por este otro: http://www.damog.net/files/hit_counter-2.phps A este nuevo archivo, tambin hay que llamarlo hit_counter.php, o sea, hay que sobreescribir el anterior. Ahora slo falta crear una tabla en la base de datos, la cual nos servir para guardar todas las IP’s. Por default, cada 15 das (cada da 7 y 21, de cada mes -gracias a Wieland por la sugerencia-) se borra la tabla, para permitir nuevamente las IP’s que hayan sido guardadas con anterioridad: 

mysql> CREATE TABLE ipvisitor (ip VARCHAR(255));

Y listo! ;-)

Cul es la diferencia exacta entre un contador de hits y uno de visitas?

Es muy simple. Un hit counter suma un dgito en cada recarga del sitio (o en cada momento que la parte del script del hit counter es ejectuado, o ‘mandado llamar’). Un visit counter, cuenta visitas reales, suma un dgito cuando una IP diferente ejecuta el script. Enjoy.

Post.title: Visa aprobada
Post._content:
Pues el da de hoy fui a la embajada americana por primera vez en mi pueril vida. La cita estaba fijada a las 8 de la maana, por lo cual llegu a las 7:30. Para mi sorpresa vi un mundo interminable de gente, haba muchsima gente: Personas de traje, seoras pedorras sintindose chingonas por que van a Estados Unidos, hipsters, nios fresas, pero tambin mucha gente humilde, sombrerudos, viejos y viejas, seoras gordas que llevan banquitos, viejas estpidas que no paran de hablar y poner nervioso a todo mundo.

A las 7:30 me ape en la denominada fila de las 8, luego de que nos reacomodaron a todos varias veces estuve parado en la fila, soportando el puto fro de mierda durante tres horas y media. Luego de la fila inicial entramos al tunelcito donde te revisan la solicitud, el pago y el pasaporte. Al entrar te hacen que te quites todo, a algunos hasta los zapatos (cosa que tambin vi que hacan soldados venezolanos en el Aeropuerto Internacional de Maiqueta, en Venezuela), luego te dan tu turno y te formas en una primera sala. Yo no saba ni qu pedo as que cuando toc mi turno en la primera sala, yo pens que el tipo sentado ah era el consul. Me pregunt a qu iba a los EEUU y me tom fotos y me tom huellas. Me dijo que me fuera a la segunda sala de espera.

Esa segunda sala era la de espera a la entrevista con los cnsules. Mi turno era el 450 e iban en el 380. Esper como media hora y me toc en la ltima ventanilla. La consul, la neta, estaba algo guapa y me habl con un espaol muy gringo. Estuve un minuto parado frente a la consul, donde le mostr la carta de Nekotec y contest un par de preguntas. “Su visa ha sido aprobada, entregue este ticket en mensajera”. Y ya. Ms nada, casi cinco horas despus, estaba saliendo de la embajada.

Lo de siempre: Pues resulta que slo iba con veinte varos, pues me fui en metro (mi coche no circula los mircoles). Cuando me aprobaron mi visa y fui a la mensajera a dejar mis datos para que la entreguen (hasta dentro de un mes :-S), vi que el costo era de 45 pesos. Me lleva la chingada. Por qu ese tipo de pendejadas slo me pasa a m? Cmo me iba a ver, luego de que un consul me haba aprobado la visa y pidindole a alguien que me prestara 45 varos para pagar la puta mensajera? Con mi falta de pena en esas ocasiones, me acerqu a un gey bien von-dutch que me haba tocado en la fila. “Qu onda? Oye, un favor, la neta no traigo un peso y no saba que cobraban la mensajera”. Sud un poco. “S, no hay pedo, toma”. “Ahorita vamos al cajero y te paso la lana”. Asinti. Pagu. Salimos. Me dice: “Si quieres mejor invtame un caf en el Starbucks y ah muere”. Dud y acept, pero en el camino le pregunt a un cerdo: “Oiga poli, un cajero?”. Indic que a 30 metros estaba uno, caminamos, saqu dinero, le pagu y nos despedimos. Llegu al cruce del ngel de la Independencia y llam a mi gordita de requesn con nopales :)

Post.title: Vctimas
Post._content: Cuando me pongo a pensar y dejar volar la mente imaginando cmo puede ser estar en un tnel donde cien personas empujan hacia una salida minscula, trancada por la polica, siento una muy, aunque breve, incmoda desesperacin. Imagina que te falta el aire; que por ms que quieres zafarte de la multitud, no puedes; intentas abrir espacio, pero tus tristes brazos son impotentes contra el choque humano; la vista se te empieza a nublar, te sientes dbil, te duele el pecho y los pulmones, sudas fro, sientes el sudor en el cuello y de repente lo dejas de sentir. Gritas, o intentas hacerlo, pero tu voz se sofoca; sabes que duele, pero empiezas a olvidar el dolor. Gente alrededor de ti hace exactamente lo mismo. Imagina si t, que pesas cien kilos y mides casi un metro ochenta, experimentas todas esas sensaciones, qu sentir una muchachita de uno cincuenta, de 55 kilos, en la misma situacin que t, est al lado de ti, llorando, sufriendo, muriendo. Y luego mueren los dos asfixiados. Dejas de sufrir porque has muerto. Y tu compaera, con la que diez minutos antes estabas bailando en la pista, coqueteando y tomando una cerveza, te esperaba muerta minutos antes. Al final, son trece los que, como t, murieron en la misma situacin. De verdad que es bien lamentable, triste, inconcebible, que la polica provoque sto. Cmo es posible. Cmo. Y qu hicieron al respecto Felipe Caldern, Marcelo Ebrard, Joel Ortega? Puta bola de bufones infelices muertos de hambre. Ojetes de mierda. Intenta imaginar, tan slo por un instante, cmo pudo haber sido y qu debi haber sentido la gente. Recomiendo mucho esta columna de Jacobo Zabludovsky.

Post.title: Viaje por el Bltico
Post._content:
Estoy haciendo planes para que, al llegar a Helsinki, pueda hacer un viaje relmpago alrededor de la capital finlandesa. Mi ruta sera como la del mapa (hacer clic):



Llegar a Helsinki el mircoles 6 de julio, por la tarde, como a las 6 7. Como seguramente llegar muerto (ya me pas al ir a Madrid en mayo), me echar como tronco y seguramente amanecer hasta el da siguiente. El da 7 inspeccionar la zona (el HUT, que es donde nos quedamos), y el da 8 pretendo salir, como al medioda, con rumbo a Tallin, Estonia, pas que est situado al sur de Finlandia, slo separados por el Golfo de Finlandia. Para llegar, tomar un ferry que hace alrededor de 3 horas.

Llegando a Tallinn como a las 4 de la tarde, buscar uno de los hostels que tengo ya investigados y saldr a conocer y en la noche proceder a conocer la vida nocturna. Al da siguiente, sbado 9 de julio, saldr de Tallinn y de Estonia con rumbo hacia Riga, Latvia (tambin se le llama a este pas Letonia, pero es ms comn como Latvia). Saldr de Tallin como al medioda, va autobs, y hace como 5 horas.

En Riga, har algo similar, quedarme en uno de los hostels identificados y salir a conocer y a parrandear. Al da siguiente, domingo 10 de julio (da en que oficialmente empieza el DebConf), tomar un ferry hacia Estocolmo, Suecia, alrededor de las 4 de la tarde. Para ello es necesario cruzar el Mar Bltico. Estara llegando a tierras suecas el lunes 11 de julio a las 9 de la maana (s, son ms de 15 horas por ferry).

En Estocolmo hara lo mismo, quedarme en un hostal una noche y al da siguiente, martes 12 de julio, tomara un ferry de regreso a Helsinki. Como nota cultura, el ferry hara una escala en una isla sueca llamada Mariehamn. Estara de regreso a Helsinki, como al medioda del mircoles 13 de julio, tiempo suficiente para disfrutar de DebConf y de la compaa de toda la gente involucrada.

Y hasta donde tengo entendido, no necesito visa para entrar a Estonia, ni a Latvia. Finlandia y Suecia es definitivo que no. Ojal tuviera alguien que me acompaara.

Post.title: Viaje Parte Uno
Post._content:
El da de hoy estuve en la hermosa ciudad de Guadalajara, Jal. en la Feria Internacional del Libro, la ms grande de Latinoamrica. Asist principalmente por la presencia de Quino, creador de Mafalda, y tambin para saludar a Sandra y Claudia, de las cuales slo pude ver a la primera, debido a que el celular de Claudia nunca estuvo activo.

En fin, llegu a eso de las 7:20 de la maana sin tener rumbo. En una ciudad que desconozco por completo, llegu al sitio de taxis de la central de autobuses:

Damog: “En cunto me sale que me deje en Expo Guadalajara?”
Taxista: “En 100 pesos”.
Damog: “Chale… qu me viste cara de chilango o qu?”
Taxista: “No… La misma tarifa para todos”.

Y… ni modo. Me trep al taxi dolindome pagar 100 firulillas, ya ni el DF, ni modo, la novatada.

Llegu al lugar de la Feria, a las 7:40 AM. Aqul lugar anunciaba la hora de entrada, a las 9 AM. Ni modo, a esperar. El taxista, el cual era ya 100 pesos ms rico, me haba dicho que a escasos cinco minutos del lugar, estaba “Plaza del Sol”, que poda ir ah a hacer algo. En fin, no vi motivo alguno para quedarme afuera de la Expo Guadalajara y camin hacia el mencionado lugar. Toda aquella zona ola a caf con leche o chocolate, yo con hambre, me dej llevar esperando encontrar un Vips, Toks, Wings o algo parecido. Llegu a “Plaza del Sol” en 15 minutos. Desierto. Era demasiado temprano. Iba caminando de regreso al lugar de la Feria, cuando una mujer muy parecida a Ana Gabriela Guevara se me acerca:

Mujer: “Oye qu calle es sta?”
Damog: “No tengo la menor idea”.
Mujer: “Huh?”
Damog: “No soy de aqu… Ni de all”.
Mujer: “Huh?”

Y me alej caminando. Segua oliendo el delicioso olor a chocolate. Pas frente a un Office Max y quise entrar a ver las laptops, para ver si me iba decidiendo por alguna. El polica de la entrada me indic que hasta las 9 AM abran el lugar, eran cerca de las 8:10. Segu caminando y el olor a chocolate tuvo su porqu cuando vi la fbrica de Chocolate Ibarra frente a m. Me decepcion, quera un lugar donde comer un poco de pan y beber caf o chocolate. Volv a Expo Guadalajara y me sent a esperar a que dieran las 9 AM.

Mi hambre aumentaba. Me fui hacia la avenida ancha (:-P) y par un taxi.

Damog: “Cunto me cobra hasta un Vips, un Wings, Toks, o algo as?”
Taxista: “Pues hay uno en Plaza Mxico, o en el Centro”.
Damog: “El que quede ms cerca”.
Taxista: “Pues 40 pesos”.
Damog: “No, gracias”.

Y volv a esperar a que dieran las nueve. Por fin se abrieron las puertas de la Feria, ya haba un nmero considerable de vidos lectores y feligreses entrando y formados. Me form y pagu mi entrada.

La Feria est enorme, una gran cantidad de casas editoriales, programas, actividades. Fui a un mapa y busqu a Mlix, que segn deca su sitio, estaran presentes. No los encontr en un mapa y simplemente camin. Tom muchas fotos, en un par de das las subir y las pondr a disposicin de todos. Por fin encontr el stand de Melix y platiqu un rato con Thomas, un empedernido debianero.

La segunda y terceras partes de este relato la continuar despus. ;-)

Post.title: Viaje Parte Dos
Post._content:
En fin, luego de comprar mis cositas en el stand de Mlix, me fui a aplastar a la cafetera de la Expo. No tena nada que hacer, ya no tena a quien esperar, ni nada similar. Me trataba de comunicar al celular de Claudia, pero nunca entr la llamada. Era un pobre diablo en una ciudad pueblerina. :P

Abr mi lap y me puse a buscar en los mails que tengo almacenados. Mucha fue mi sorpresa cuando encontr entre uno de ellos, un mail de Sandra donde pona su celular, le marqu y contest.

Damog: Hola…
Sandra: Quin habla?
Damog: Tu conciencia.
Sandra: =PPPPP (eso no lo dijo, pero lo intuy).

Veinte minutos despus nos veamos en el stand de registro y estbamos prestos a entrar al homenaje de Quino.

A parte de l, se dieron cita en el lugar otros caricaturistas de talla mundial, Maitena (una tipa que no conoca), Sergio Aragons y Rius. Qu agradable verlos. Escuchamos el homenaje a Quino, Sergio Aragons le “transfiri” el premio Catrina a Quino, y tantn, se acab. Quino no firm libros y simplemente se disculp con un “salgo de Guadalajara en un rato, ya firm libros el otro da”. En fin, no lo culpo.

Eran casi las dos de la tarde y yo me mora de hambre, no haba comido nada durante la maana/tarde. Fuimos a comer unos taquitos en “Plaza del Sol” y ya despus estaba muy cansado :P

Tomamos un taxi, y Sandra me acompa hasta la central camionera. Ahora fueron 70 pesos de taxi. Me desped y abord :P

Fue una aventura mgica, cmica y musical.

The End. ;)

Post.title: Viajar
Post._content:
Me gusta viajar. Me ha gustado siempre, pero antes no me daba cuenta porque era un nio chilln. Me he dado cuenta que me gusta viajar recientemente que lo he podido hacer independientemente a mis padres, aunque ahora con nostalgia, me gustara hacerlo ms con ellos.

Viajes largos han sido algo que me han dejado impactado en los ltimos aos. Como generalmente he viajado solo, tengo mayor oportunidad para pensar en muchas cosas, del trabajo, del amor, de la familia, pero tambin puedo observar a los dems pasajeros junto conmigo.

En los ltimos aos, me he vuelto altamente antisocial, no me gusta estar con ms gente que la que conozco o la que necesito. No me gusta tomar el transporte pblico porque voy a terminar enojndome por como es la gente, porque siempre habr algo que molestar a ms de uno, y quizs ni cuenta se den. En los pocos viajes internacionales que he hecho, es a veces cuestin de rer o llorar al ver a la gente alrededor. Hay unas viejas que parece que se visten para ir al antro, al treparse a un avin, como si el estar ah les diera mayor cach, las hiciera cream de la cream. Desde luego, se ven muchos extranjeros que no son la parte representativa de lo que sus pases viven, sean o no, pases desarrollados. Ves a las chavas en pants ajustaditos, digamos, a la moda, pero gevonas a final de cuentas. Hay gente que reclama sus asientos, que exigen tener el peridico para seguramente ojearlo cinco minutos, dormirse y dejarlo tirado en el piso del avin. Todos nos ensardinamos en un avin para sentirnos internacionales, ms an en viajes a Europa, y sobre todo aquellos que, como yo, slo viajan para all muy espordicamente.

Las personas de un avin nos degradamos como seres humanos al estar empaquetados en un cabina o bveda que de repente har cambiar nuestra realidad. Entrar a un avin y luego salir de l es bastante shockeante, cambias una realidad por otra, de repente todo es diferente: El gusano por el que te introdujiste al avin, ha cambiado, el personal de los pasillos en el aeropuerto ahora hablan otro idioma, usan otros billetes y otras monedas, sienten diferente temperatura ya. Y slo te toma unas cuentas horas para cambiar de realidad. Recientemente, Raquel y yo viajamos por coche de la Ciudad de Mxico, a la frontera, Reynosa, Tamaulipas y cruzamos a McAllen, TX. Es bien triste ver cmo puede cambiar un pedazo de tierra, al cruzar la raya del mapa. En un momento me siento en una colonia popular cualquiera de Mxico y al otro instante estoy en medio de cualquier serie melodramtica estadounidense.

Apuesto que viajar acompaado de algn ser querido cambiar completamente esta percepcin, pero sto no ha sido el caso para m. Apuesto que al viajar con alguien a tu lado, debe ser ms bonito; como cuando nio, mi pap nos enseaba los volcanes que pasbamos por Puebla al ir a la Ciudad de Mxico desde Cd. del Carmen, Campeche. Creo que me hace ms de eso, dejar de preocuparme por cmo la gente me puede hacer irascible y procurar mayor tranquilidad, a final de cuentas soy una persona sumamente feliz, en todos los aspectos, estoy por fin, ya muy completo.

Por lo pronto, el da de maana salgo hacia Edimburgo. Har una escala larga, de ms de seis horas en Nueva York y luego volar a Liverpool, en donde tomar un tren que espero que sin contratiempos, me lleve a Edimburgo. De regreso es igual, con la salvedad de que Raquel me alcanzar en Nueva York, en donde pasaremos unos cuantos das, haciendo lo que siempre quise hacer: Conocer esa ciudad, caminar por sus barrios, ver la diversidad cultural, estar por unos momentos en esa atmsfera que desde siempre me ha cautivado y que desde nio he soado, quizs asistir a un juego de pelota (cosa que siempre quise hacer con mi pap, alguna vez en la vida y que espero hacerlo), en fin, tantas cosas que en este momento me hace ponerme nostlgico.

Post.title: Vetado de Planeta Linux
Post._content:
La semana pasada fue mucho muy pesada para m. Entre la guardia, los proyectos que tengo en la chamba, Ulteo y otras cosas, he quedado exhausto. De cualquier forma, durante la semana estuve revisando algunas cosas de Planeta Linux, y entre ellas he tirnicamente decidido en vetar a una persona de Planeta Linux.

Desde luego, que puede no ser gran cosa este hecho ni para la persona del blog, ni para Planeta Linux, pero siento que los usuarios se deben una explicacin. Generalmente no veto nada, no banneo a nadie (y soy ms libertino de poner blogs de tecnologa que enrriquezcan el sitio, aunque Milton y los lineamientos no estn muy de acuerdo :P), me gusta mucho la diversidad que existe en los planetas, pero simplemente me cans de un sindicado en Planeta Linux Ecuador que lo nico que hace es chingar a la gente. El blog es de un tipo egocntrico, patn, troll, engredo, credo y que hizo derramar el vaso con la gota al poner una imagen de goatse tamao familiar en su blog. Yo no me haba dado cuenta hasta que Raquel me lo dijo, con expresin entre asco, disgusto y dems. La verdad es que yo no quiero este tipo de reacciones, en primer lugar de ella y que simplemente se entretiene un poco viendo los posts en Planeta Linux, y mucho menos quiero la misma reaccin para los lectores del sitio.

Y s, no me importa aplicar el fascismo tecnolgico aqu, si alguno de los que tienen acceso para commit en el subversion de Planeta Linux, vuelve a habilitar el feed, perder inmediatamente sus privilegios en el sistema.

Post.title: Venezuela
Post._content: I was in Venezuela last week.Something special happened. No, it is not only that I was able to see my beloved girl; it is not that the free software community and free software efforts and project rock. No, something very personal and special.I arrived at Maiqueta (roughly, international airport of Caracas) from Maracaibo around 9 pm. At around 10 or 10:30 I was on my way to the hotel on a van where they pick up and down people on the airport-hotel-airport basis. I was waiting for my early flight to Mexico City the next day (on Sunday, at 8 am).On our way to the hotel, I asked a lady sitting next to me: “So, how far away from Maiqueta is Caracas?”. “Around 40 or 45 minutes”, she said. Ah, nice, next time I come to Venezuela I definitively should go to Caracas, I thought.”You’re Mexican, aren’t you?”. “Yes”, smiling. “I’m going to Mexico tomorrow”, she said, also smiling. “Are you in the Mexicana 8 am flight?”, I asked, being curious. And she was. We talked a bit more and apparently she was coming also from Maracaibo on my same flight, now that’s a coincidence. “It is my first time in Mexico tomorrow”, so it was mine in Venezuela.Arriving to the hotel, we checked in and went to rooms. On the morning, at the next day, I found her on the hotel-airport van again. I thougth she was going to be already on the hotel, specially since I was late for almost an hour, but no, she was there. “So we are late, eh?”, she asked me. “I think so”.After exhausting militar revision (four times, with four different soldiers: Political relationship between Mexico and Venezuela is not healthy nowadays), I documented my baggage. The lady was in the executive line and I was with mortals. She was pregnat, also. The lady on the desk gave the boarding pass (at that point we were supposed to be already on the gate, one hour before time) and pointed me another desk where I was supposed to pay airport taxes. Now, that is scary, since I was not carrying too much on bills or coins. I arrived to the desk: “how much is it?”. “105’000 bolvares”, around 50 USD. God dammit, I was only carrying 45’000 and my credit cards are broken. At that sudden time, I was already thinking I should be spending a couple more days to get that fucking cash and pay for the change of flight, etc. Or… I could ask for help to the lady. What do I lose if she says no?- Mrs, I have a real problem, and I need help. Anyway, I will truly understand if you are not able to do it, but I’d much appreciated it.- What happen?- I need to borrow 60’000 Bs from you, please, please. I don’t have enough to pay for the taxes and my credit cards are completely broken, I didn’t think on taxes when spending money on anything else before.- Don’t worry, let’s go to the ATM.There. There I go. That completely unknown nice lady helping me to not lose my flight.- But I have to go first to a Internet center to make a transaction online to be able to get cash from the ATM.- Yeah, of course, I’ll go with you- What else could I do?She took the cash off and went together again to the taxes desk. She gave me the money and we both paid. Only 15 or 20 minutes were left for the flight to departure and we were trying to do things fast. Fortunately, we both did it since more cops and soldiers were making inspections just on the airplane’s door.When she was on the line I went to the phone booths to make a call home.- Mom, I need you to bring 300 pesos when you go pick me up to the airport. Long story.- No problem.And the lady was not there anymore, I was unable to see her again (probably because she was on executive or because she was an angel :-). When we landed, I didn’t see her again on the plane, in the lines, in the police line, etc. I have no idea how that happened, but it happened.She will be awarded with twins :)She was wearing a David’s shield on her neckless, by the way.
Post.raw: title: "Venezuela" date: 2005/11/28 00:13:06 Tags: --- I was in Venezuela last week.Something special happened. No, it is not only that I was able to see my beloved girl; it is not that the free software community and free software efforts and project rock. No, something very personal and special.I arrived at Maiqueta (roughly, international airport of Caracas) from Maracaibo around 9 pm. At around 10 or 10:30 I was on my way to the hotel on a van where they pick up and down people on the airport-hotel-airport basis. I was waiting for my early flight to Mexico City the next day (on Sunday, at 8 am).On our way to the hotel, I asked a lady sitting next to me: “So, how far away from Maiqueta is Caracas?”. “Around 40 or 45 minutes”, she said. Ah, nice, next time I come to Venezuela I definitively should go to Caracas, I thought.”You’re Mexican, aren’t you?”. “Yes”, smiling. “I’m going to Mexico tomorrow”, she said, also smiling. “Are you in the Mexicana 8 am flight?”, I asked, being curious. And she was. We talked a bit more and apparently she was coming also from Maracaibo on my same flight, now that’s a coincidence. “It is my first time in Mexico tomorrow”, so it was mine in Venezuela.Arriving to the hotel, we checked in and went to rooms. On the morning, at the next day, I found her on the hotel-airport van again. I thougth she was going to be already on the hotel, specially since I was late for almost an hour, but no, she was there. “So we are late, eh?”, she asked me. “I think so”.After exhausting militar revision (four times, with four different soldiers: Political relationship between Mexico and Venezuela is not healthy nowadays), I documented my baggage. The lady was in the executive line and I was with mortals. She was pregnat, also. The lady on the desk gave the boarding pass (at that point we were supposed to be already on the gate, one hour before time) and pointed me another desk where I was supposed to pay airport taxes. Now, that is scary, since I was not carrying too much on bills or coins. I arrived to the desk: “how much is it?”. “105’000 bolvares”, around 50 USD. God dammit, I was only carrying 45’000 and my credit cards are broken. At that sudden time, I was already thinking I should be spending a couple more days to get that fucking cash and pay for the change of flight, etc. Or… I could ask for help to the lady. What do I lose if she says no?- Mrs, I have a real problem, and I need help. Anyway, I will truly understand if you are not able to do it, but I’d much appreciated it.- What happen?- I need to borrow 60’000 Bs from you, please, please. I don’t have enough to pay for the taxes and my credit cards are completely broken, I didn’t think on taxes when spending money on anything else before.- Don’t worry, let’s go to the ATM.There. There I go. That completely unknown nice lady helping me to not lose my flight.- But I have to go first to a Internet center to make a transaction online to be able to get cash from the ATM.- Yeah, of course, I’ll go with you- What else could I do?She took the cash off and went together again to the taxes desk. She gave me the money and we both paid. Only 15 or 20 minutes were left for the flight to departure and we were trying to do things fast. Fortunately, we both did it since more cops and soldiers were making inspections just on the airplane’s door.When she was on the line I went to the phone booths to make a call home.- Mom, I need you to bring 300 pesos when you go pick me up to the airport. Long story.- No problem.And the lady was not there anymore, I was unable to see her again (probably because she was on executive or because she was an angel :-). When we landed, I didn’t see her again on the plane, in the lines, in the police line, etc. I have no idea how that happened, but it happened.She will be awarded with twins :)She was wearing a David’s shield on her neckless, by the way.

Post.title: Updates
Post._content:
• Personal stuff coming up; if you are not that kind of person, please skip :-)
  • I forgot to say on my previous post about YAPC::NA 2008 that while I was in Chicago, I had the really nice chance to meet Carlo Segre and Dirk Eddelbuettel and enjoy a couple of nice beers with them. Great guys!
  • I'm probably not attending DebConf this year. It's just too expensive right now and since sponsorship appears to be not enough, chances for me are quite low now. The cheapest I can get from NYC is around $1050/1100, which might be cheap for some folks in Europe which paid the same amount in Euros, but not for me now.
  • I'm not attending OSCON neither. I wanted to, I really did, but it'll have to be next year now, because...
  • On that days, I'll be in Mexico City with Raquel renewing our visas. Almost one year already since we got here, time flies.
  • Last Friday (Fourth of July), we were invited by Mike and Rachel O'Connor to a barbeque at their place in Brooklyn. Even though they are veggies, they had some meat sausages and burgers which were great (also the grilled corn!). We watched the fireworks from their roof, which I have to say, weren't as spectacular as I expected, but it was probably because we weren't very, very close to Manhattan or because a big building was blocking our view in front of us, or because of the rain. A bunch of their friends were also there. I enjoyed spending time with them and Mr. Micah Anderson and Sr. Abraham Estrada. By the way...
  • There will be a Debian NYC BSP very soon now! Stay tuned! Represent! :P
  • I've been playing more chess that it should be legal, as some of you may have already realized.
  • I gave myself a present and bought a PSP. I now do alley-oops, slam dunks and all kind of dribbles on NBA Live 2008 on my morning commute ;-)
  • And last; for my personal workstation, I'm trying now Ubuntu Hardy and I'm doing a personal project with Rails. I have to say that even though I had some encountered feelings about both of them, I've been having quite a nice surprise and experience with both.

Post.title: Uno de los tropezones ms dolorosos de los Pumas
Post._content:
Ayer fui con mi pap al Estadio Olmpico Universitario a ver a los Pumas de la UNAM jugar contra el Unin Atltico Maracaibo, equipo venezolano, compaero de grupo en la Copa Toyota Libertadores.

En el partido de presentacin de los Pumas, all en Uruguay contra el Nacional, habamos cado por 2-0. Ahora, en la presentacin de los Pumas en la Libertadores estando en casa, perdimos. No puedo creer eso. Si eso nos pasa con un equipo como Maracaibo que encontr el gol por suerte y que se defendi a ms no poder, no quiero pensar en el desempeo del equipo con otros ms grandes sudamericanos. Marioni fall una cantidad impresionante de balones, Victorino no se quedaba atrs, slo se puede decir que los nicos que jugaron bien fueron Sergio Bernal y Leandro Augusto, al menos en lo que cabe.

Toda la aficin tristsima, mentndole la madre a Marioni y a Espaa, los goyas que se cantaban no era para animar a los gevones que llevan al puma en el pecho, era para salvar la dignidad del equipo universitario. Recuerden, pinches Pumas, por qu estn ah: Por haber sido campeones del Clausura 2004 y del Apertura 2004, recuerden la gloria del bicampeonato, la dignidad de ser los humildes bicampeones. El Maracaibo nos gan en casa, con alrededor de 20 25 mil aficinados de los Pumas y cuntos aficionados del Maracaibo? Si haba 15 20 personas era mucho. No quiero saber cmo nos va a ir cuando vayan a territorio zuliano a disputar el 30 de marzo el partido de regreso contra los maracuchos.

Adems, en el torneo de liga Clausura 2006, el sbado pasado, los Pumas perdieron 3-1 contra el Cruz Azul en el Estadio Azul, la cabeza de Miguel Espaa y de Bruno Marioni tienen que rodar ya.

Por la dignidad universitaria. Entiendan lo que tienen puesto, sientan la pinche camiseta, el amor a los colores de la UNAM no se quita tan fcilmente, no se puede llegar a ser tan mediocres tan fcilmente. Es inslito.

Post.title: Un par de buenas noticias
Post._content:
Pues el da de hoy he recibido sendas agradables noticias.

En primer lugar, he sido aprobado en la etapa Tasks and Skills, del proceso de Nuevo Mantenedor, lo cual significa que estoy cerca de convertirme en desarrollador oficial de Debian.

Ms especficamente significa que ya no depende tanto de m, si no simplemente esperar un par de etapas, que ya no dependen del todo de m. Todo lo que hubiera podido haber dicho, o hecho, ya est en el pasado.

Craig Small fue mi AM, durante el proceso. Generalmente la etapa del AM termina con su aprobacin, y la ma precisamente lleg hoy. Ahora viene la parte pesada: Esperar.

El ltimo mantenedor que fue aceptado en Debian, fue en julio pasado. Fue Jaime Robles, que tambin es desarrollador de KDE. Desde ese momento para ac, estn esperando ese ltimo paso cerca de setenta personas. Una larga fila.

Mako me comentaba que Martin Michlmayr, actual lder del proyecto Debian, al convertirse en tal, aprob una gran cantidad de desarrolladores en poco tiempo, que slo esperaban al DAM (creacin de cuentas). Ojal algo similar ocurra pronto ;-)

En fin, esa fue una noticia. La otra fue el hermoso triunfo de los Pumas de la Universidad. Slo tengo una palabra para eso: Soberbio. Vamos por el bicampeonato.

Por cierto, el fin de semana fui a Ixmiquilpan. Puse las aventuras de dicho viaje en mi blog debianoso.

Ya se acerca Navidad, y esperando no convertirme en el Grinch que he sido todo el ao, espero gozarlo y disfrutarlo con mis paps y hermana. Y desde luego, mis amiguitos.

:-)

Current Mood: mischievous

Post.title: Un amor ms en mi vida
Post._content: No puede pasar ms tiempo sin que escriba sobre el nuevo amor en mi vida: Una linda PowerBook que compr el da de ayer y la bautic con el nombre de Gordita (aunque no est nada gordita, siendo quizs la mquina ms delgada que he tenido).Caractersticas rpidas: PowerBook G41.67GHz, 15 para 1280x864, 512MB memoria, 80GB disco duro, Super drive, Airport Extreme, Bluetooth y otras moneras.Lo bueno.Como es bien sabido, las tarjetas inalmbricas Airport Extreme de Broadcom no funcionan en Linux (aunque hay un proyecto que est haciendo progresos), sin embargo al ser ste un modulo ms grande, tiene un slot PCMCIA donde le puedo poner una tarjeta inalmbrica y listo.Durante toda mi vida, desde por ah del 99, nunca haba tenido una pantalla con mayor resolucin a 1024x768, tener un poquito ms es super chido y me llena de emocin.An no he visto qu onda con el quemador de DVDs, pero no debe tener mayor problema. Tampoco con el dispositivo Bluetooth.Lo malo.Flash no funciona. Java no funciona en la versin de Sun.Lo feo.Cuando se calienta mucho, el CD empieza a hacer un pitido bien pinche molesto (de sto quizs necesite llevarla YA a un centro de servicio de Apple).La foto. La neta s estoy bien felipe :)

Post.title: Two new packages
Post._content:
I uploaded two new packages today, GParted and fteqcc.

Random thoughts:

  • In the next days, I’ll be using some of the patches made available in the CVS for gparted. The version that’ll hit unstable is raw 0.0.8.
  • fteqcc is the FTE QuakeC compiler, which between other things, will make possible for nexuiz to enter the archive. This was the first step to bring nexuiz officially to Debian.
  • Being suscribed to debian-wnpp@lists.debian.org is quite fun and you always can help a bit people dealing with wnpp bugs.
  • Pretending you don’t need glasses doesn’t work anymore. I have received the ones I ordered last week today and now I can see clearly, heh.
  • I’m getting ready to start my portuguese lessons on the Brazilian embassy in middle September.
Post.raw:
title: "Two new packages" date: 2005/8/29 05:24:13 Tags: ---

I uploaded two new packages today, GParted and fteqcc.

Random thoughts:

  • In the next days, I’ll be using some of the patches made available in the CVS for gparted. The version that’ll hit unstable is raw 0.0.8.
  • fteqcc is the FTE QuakeC compiler, which between other things, will make possible for nexuiz to enter the archive. This was the first step to bring nexuiz officially to Debian.
  • Being suscribed to debian-wnpp@lists.debian.org is quite fun and you always can help a bit people dealing with wnpp bugs.
  • Pretending you don’t need glasses doesn’t work anymore. I have received the ones I ordered last week today and now I can see clearly, heh.
  • I’m getting ready to start my portuguese lessons on the Brazilian embassy in middle September.

Post.title: Two Git tips
Post._content:
Following the Git tips being thrown on Planet Debian, here's a couple: 1. Changing into a directory that contains a repo and shows you on PS1 what branch you are standing on:
On .bashrc I have: 
GITPS1='$(__git_ps1 ":%s ")'
export PS1="${GREEN}\w${RS} ${YELLOW}${GITPS1}${RS}\\$ "
2. An alias I like to use on repos that are personal for quick tracking: 
[alias]
  ...
  log1 = log --pretty=oneline --abbrev-commit
I hope you like them.

Post.title: TwitVim: Nice Twitter client
Post._content:
I do like Twitter. For quite some time now I've been trying to find a Twitter client that I'd really like. I've tried, lots of them, Twhirl, Twitux, microblog-purple (which I started to dislike since I'm not IMing that much anymore and it can become extremely annoying if not blocked), TweetDeck, etc. All of them don't seem to fill my own needs and preferences. Even when Twitter used to support IM, I came up with probably the best solution I've used so far, GTalk on Bitlbee, so I could easily use Irssi with it. I have also been suggested to use Twidge but direct command-line IO is probably not the best for me. I want to have it a console emulator window, maybe screened in a remote server, running all the time, auto-updating, unobstrusive. Given this, I started to hack on my own personal client using ncurses. Sadly, my lack of deep knowledge of the not-too-intuitive ncurses API made me abort the project. Maybe some day I could retake it. Shame. Anyway, within the last week, I found and have been using TwitVim. I like Vim: It's my editor of choice for most of my projects. And TwitVim is a really nice project supporting a lot of interesting features:

There you can see how, on a non-obstrusive way, you can have it running. Since it's built on Vim, you can also do some key mappings so that you don't have to type all the commands. And it has all sorts of really cool and interesting features, like if the cursor is on a given line, \r will start a reply, or other binding will start a direct message, etc. Here's a picture of my own timeline:

Once you have installed it, take a look at the extensive and detailed documentation with: 
:help TwitVim
However, the only downside is that it doesn't auto-refresh. But you can map a key for quick update: 
:nnoremap <F8> :FriendsTwitter<cr>
What Twitter clients do you like and use?

Post.title: Twitter's OAuth + Perl
Post._content: During the last week, unbeatable Tatsuhiko Miyagawa uploaded Net::Twitter::OAuth to CPAN, which provides an awesome interface for Net::OAuth::Simple and Twitter by subclassing Net::Twitter. This way, it's very easy to develop Twitter client applications using its new OAuth method dropping the need for users to hand their credentials to third parties. You will have to register your application on Twitter previously. You can do so here. If this is a web application that you will be building, you can provide a callback URL which is the page where the user will get redirected once she has granted access to your application. If you just want to test, setting a desktop application is probably the way to go. Once you have registered your application, you will get two strings, key and secret consumer. Refer to general OAuth documentation for deeper details. Install Net::Twitter::OAuth as any other Perl module: [shell] $ sudo cpan Net::Twitter::OAuth [/shell] Now, using it is very simple: my $client = Net::Twitter::OAuth->new( consumer_key => "YOUR-CONSUMER-KEY", consumer_secret => "YOUR-CONSUMER-SECRET", ); No transactions or requests have been made yet. Here you need the user's access and secret tokens. If you already have them, which means that the user has already gone through the authorization process, you have to pass it now (you already stored them on database, a configuration file or whatever the data model you use): if ($access_token && $access_token_secret) { $client->oauth->access_token($access_token); $client->oauth->access_token_secret($access_token_secret); } Now you can query Twitter so it can provide you access: unless ($client->oauth->authorized) { # The client is not yet authorized: Do it now print "Authorize this app at ", $client->oauth->get_authorization_url, " and hit RET\n"; ; # wait for input my($access_token, $access_token_secret) = $client->oauth->request_access_token; save_tokens($access_token, $access_token_secret); # if necessary } All these snippets come from the example's of Net::Twitter::OAuth. So basically, if you are not authorized, which means that either the user hasn't even been prompted for authorization or denied access before, then you get the authorization URL which you can give to the user to visit. Once the user has granted access, you can call request_access_token which will return the user's tokens. Here's where you can save those tokens for future use. After that block, you are pretty much done and can use the regular Net::Twitter methods: my $res = $client->update({ status => 'me ownz oauth!!1' }); Soon, a real life application post using HTTP::Engine, KiokuDB and Net::Twitter::OAuth.
Post.raw: title: "Twitter's OAuth + Perl" date: 2009/5/21 14:06:42 tags: - oauth - perl - twitter --- During the last week, unbeatable Tatsuhiko Miyagawa uploaded Net::Twitter::OAuth to CPAN, which provides an awesome interface for Net::OAuth::Simple and Twitter by subclassing Net::Twitter. This way, it's very easy to develop Twitter client applications using its new OAuth method dropping the need for users to hand their credentials to third parties. You will have to register your application on Twitter previously. You can do so here. If this is a web application that you will be building, you can provide a callback URL which is the page where the user will get redirected once she has granted access to your application. If you just want to test, setting a desktop application is probably the way to go. Once you have registered your application, you will get two strings, key and secret consumer. Refer to general OAuth documentation for deeper details. Install Net::Twitter::OAuth as any other Perl module: [shell] $ sudo cpan Net::Twitter::OAuth [/shell] Now, using it is very simple: my $client = Net::Twitter::OAuth->new( consumer_key => "YOUR-CONSUMER-KEY", consumer_secret => "YOUR-CONSUMER-SECRET", ); No transactions or requests have been made yet. So basically, if you are not authorized, which means that either the user hasn't even been prompted for authorization or denied access before, then you get the authorization URL which you can give to the user to visit. Post.title: Twenty-one
Post._content:
A day like today, but 21 years ago, I was born. Random thoughts:

  • I hosted a birthday party last friday. All my dearest friends were there.
  • I’m now able to drink with abrotman in Philadelphia! ;-)
  • It sucks that my back-to-school day is my birthday.
  • Tato, one of my high school homies, will also be 21 on the 11st.
  • I felt asleep on my own party last friday because I was too drunk (at 1:30 am). My guests left around 4 or 5. That happens when you are still 20 ;-)
  • I watched a The Simpsons episode today where Bart is feeling he is not a kid anymore.
  • This is actually the beginning of my third decade of life. And saying that sounds like 30s.
  • I’m getting old very quickly.

Post.title: "True ska is music with soul". -Prince Buster.
Post._content:
Pues, para no perder la costumbre, he estado escuchando una estacin de radio por Internet, muy buena, de ska.

Ska Jerk es en s un sitio ms de informacin relacionada al ska, reggae, rock steady, mento y dems msica de buena vibra. Un sitio con informacin, enlaces, galera fotogrfica, historia, etc.

Lo que hace a Ska Jerk un fenomenal sitio de reunin es precisamente la estacin que tienen al aire. Estn conectados a travs de los servidores de Live 365, lo cual los dota de un excelente ancho de banda y se permiten tener a cientos de usuarios conectados escuchando la estacin.

Lo que me gusta de Ska Jerk es que no slo es ska de primera ola. No slo es ska tradicional, tambin programan ska postsesentero, de segunda y tercera ola, algo de ska punk, e incluso ska fusin. Me ha tocado escuchar desde los maestros Skatalites, Madness y Toasters, hasta los Mighty Mighty Bosstones, Reel Big Fish e incluso a Inspector. Ska de todas partes del mundo, o si no es ska, sonidos muy similares e invariablemente agradables.

Ska Jerk ofrece incluso su playlist, la cual es un excelente recurso para buscar muchas canciones a partir de ah. Y como podr verse, no se estancan en determinadas pocas o determinados grupos. Est interesante darse una vuelta por el sitio. Puro skavoovie por ah.

Se puede accesar al sitio en:
http://members.tripod.com/rytradska/

Y para escuchar la estacin, basta dirigir el reproductor de mp3 hacia:
http://www.live365.com/play/skajerk.

Post.title: Trip to Central America
Post._content:
I have started planning (and saving) a trip through Central America.

I’d be flying to Panama City. Then San Jos, Managua, Tegucigalpa and Guatemala. And then back to Mexico City. The only country I would not visit in Central America because it is out of the route is Belize.

I’m getting excited because of this. I hope somebody would like to join me. I hate being alone when traveling.
